newsitem.title: USA: MUNI BUYSIDE - Munis should weather $4 bln deluge.
newsitem.headline: MUNI BUYSIDE - Munis should weather $4 bln deluge.

text.p: Fresh municipal debt totalling $4 billion is set to flood the market next week, but at least one portfolio manager believes it will do little to dampen prices.

"I think the muni market is going to handle it well, quite frankly," said Reid Smith, a senior portfolio manager and principal at Vanguard Group. "We are at cheap enough ratios (to U.S. Treasuries) that it has brought in crossover buyers, arbitrage buyers (and) I think the insurance companies continue to be strong buyers in here."
Bond fund participation is likely to remain "somewhat anemic" given poor cash flows, Smith said.
Another market participant said AMG Data Services reported outflows of $93.916 million from municipal bond funds in the latest reporting week.
While recent flows have been thin, Smith said they are probably sufficient to provide "at least some buying from that sector."
Duration-wise, some funds may now find themselves a little shorter than they would like given the market's recent rally, he said, and may decide to venture out longer on the curve.
"So they may chase it a little bit," Smith said, adding that fund managers can justify purchases because municipals are cheap to Treasuries.
"So it's an opportune time to get some fresh cash bonds into the portfolio," he said.
Players can also look ahead to the January effect, when a substantial fresh cash from Jan 1 coupons and calls typically pours back to investors.
A municipal analyst who preferred to remain anonymous said he agreed in part with Smith, but was less confident that municipals would stand up well.
While the analyst expects the deals to go "reasonably well," much will depend on "where the Street kind of stands," he said.

"I mean it was a heavy week for bid lists, and I think people are okay from position standpoints," the analyst said. "But (if) you get heavy supply and it doesn't go away, it could get backed up in a hurry."
